channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Chief Loses Support in Stronghold
item.description: The defections of two prominent businessmen in eastern Ukraine, a stronghold for President Viktor F. Yanukovych, signal growing frustrations with him even among his base.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Joseph Sywenkyj for The New York Times
item.media:description: The European Union flag outside the Passage mall in Dnepropetrovsk, Ukraine, a gesture of revolt in a Russian-speaking region.

item.title: Lens Blog: Looted, but Not Lost: An African Artist’s Life Work
item.description: Amid the looting in Bangui, Central African Republic, Jerome Delay happened on photographic materials scattered on the ground. It turns out, they belong to the renowned photographer Samuel Fosso.
item.dc:creator: By JEROME DELAY
item.media:credit: Samuel Fosso, Courtesy of Galerie Jean-Marc Patras, Paris
item.media:description: From “The Emperor of Africa.” Self-portrait as Mao Zedong. 2013.

item.title: India Ink: India Looks to Expand Visa-on-Arrival Program to 180 Countries
item.description: Citizens from the United States and China would be among those eligible for the streamlined visa process.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: Google Settles Its European Antitrust Case; Critics Remain
item.description: If approved, the deal would put an end to half a decade of wrangles with antitrust authorities across the globe.
item.dc:creator: By CLAIRE CAIN MILLER and MARK SCOTT

item.title: Renowned Japanese Composer Admits Fraud
item.description: Japan reacted with remorse and outrage to Mamoru Samuragochi’s admission that he had hired a ghostwriter since the 1990s to compose most of his music.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: U.S. Bomber Training Run Imperils Family Reunions in Korea
item.description: North Korea is worried about military exercises by the United States and South Korea, and may cancel planned meetings of families torn apart by war.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: India Ink: In Jaipur, New Feminists Are Born
item.description: In this installment of their India tour diary, the women’s rights activists Ruchira Gupta and Gloria Steinem are determined to make their presentation at the city’s literature festival an organizing meeting, not just a one-way speech.
item.dc:creator: By RUCHIRA GUPTA
item.media:description: Gloria Steinem, left, and Ruchira Gupta, both women's rights activists, at the Jaipur Literature Festival in Rajasthan.

item.title: Members of Russian Punk Band Get Warm Greeting in Brooklyn
item.description: More than a month after their release from prison in Russia, two members of Pussy Riot are finding many allies in their fight for free expression.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MELENA RYZIK
item.media:description: Maria Alyokhina, left, and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: ‘An American in Madras’ Traces Career of Unlikely Pioneer in Tamil-Language Films
item.description: The documentary’s director, Karan Bali, said Ellis R. Dungan, who made movies in the southern state of Tamil Nadu during the 1930s and 1940, introduced innovative techniques to the fledgling Tamil film industry.
item.dc:creator: By VISI TILAK
item.media:description: American director Ellis R. Dungan, left, with actors on the sets of the film "Ponmudi."

item.title: Racing to Save the Stray Dogs of Sochi
item.description: A Russian billionaire has donated money for a shelter in a bid to save some of the hundreds of stray dogs that are being killed in preparation for the Sochi Olympic Games.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Dogs outside a snowboarding course in Sochi. Many of the strays are abandoned pets.

item.title: The Lede: No, Oxfam Has Not Called for a Boycott of Israel
item.description: The antipoverty group Oxfam rejected claims that it has called for a boycott of Israel.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Jihadist Return Is Said to Drive Attacks in Egypt
item.description: Egypt has been largely insulated from the Islamist violence in the region, but it is now facing increasing terrorism as Egyptians return from jihad abroad to fight the country’s military-backed government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A policeman at the site of a fatal car bomb blast on Jan. 24 at Egyptian security headquarters in Cairo, one of four attacks that day.

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Cuban Doctor Seeks Asylum
item.description: Ramona Rodríguez, 51, sought refuge on Tuesday in the office of a congressman after complaining that Cuba’s communist government takes too big a slice of her pay, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: South Africa: Nine Miners Missing
item.description: South African emergency workers rescued eight miners trapped in Harmony Gold’s Doornkop mine but a search went on for nine others still unaccounted for more than a day later.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Iraqi Tribes to Take Lead in Falluja Fight, U.S. Says
item.description: Brett McGurk, a top State Department official, provided new details about the Iraqi government’s effort to regain control of a key Sunni city now occupied by jihadists.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and DURAID ADNAN

item.title: Russia Blocks Yogurt Bound for U.S. Athletes
item.description: The Russian government has blocked a shipment of Chobani yogurt that had been bound for the United States Olympic team, prompting protests from yogurt-promoting politicians in New York and in Washington, who express outrage that American athletes could be deprived of the protein-rich food.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS KAPLAN

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Anti-Semitic Incidents Fall
item.description: A Jewish advisory body said the decline may have been due to a recent lack of “trigger events” in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Internet Curbs Approved
item.description: Parliament approved legislation allowing Turkey’s telecommunications authority to block websites without a prior court decision.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: Final Approval Is Given on East Jerusalem Apartments
item.description: The 500 new apartments are in neighborhoods, in territory Israel captured during the 1967 war and later annexed, that are considered illegal settlements by most of the world.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Cost Dispute Halts Work on Project to Expand Panama Canal
item.description: The canal authority and the construction consortium in charge of the project blame each other for $1.6 billion in cost overruns.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: In Spain, Fired for Speaking Out
item.description: Financial shenanigans, text messages and an ousted editor.
item.dc:creator: By PEDRO J. RAMÍREZ

item.title: Baghdad Journal: Preserving Routine Amid Rising Violence
item.description: Bombings have ebbed but have never retreated over the years in the working-class Shaab area of Baghdad.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: A policeman guided traffic last month in the Shaab neighborhood of Baghdad, where people have stopped tallying the number of bombings.

item.title: Pussy Riot Members Take Tour to New York
item.description: Two women from the Russian punk group said they had no fear of prison and suggested they may even run for political office in Russia someday.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Alyokhina, 25, left, and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova, 24, spoke with the editorial board of The New York Times on Wednesday.

item.title: How Did Your Recent Peace Corps Service Affect Your Life?
item.description: The Times invites recent Peace Corps volunteers to share how their service affected their lives after they concluded their commitment.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Qatari Court Rejects U.S. Couple’s Request to Return Home
item.description: The court said the verdict in the case against Matthew and Grace Huang, accused of starving their adopted African daughter to death, would be announced March 27.
item.dc:creator: By SHABINA S. KHATRI
